title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Previously

library(tidymodels)
library(censored)
library(splines)

data(cat_adoption)

cat_adoption <- 
  cat_adoption %>% 
  mutate(event_time = Surv(time, event), .keep = "unused", .before = everything()) 

set.seed(27)
in_demo <- sample.int(nrow(cat_adoption), 50)
demo_cats <- cat_adoption %>% slice(in_demo)

set.seed(123)
cat_split <- initial_split(cat_adoption %>% slice(-in_demo), prop = 0.8)
cat_train <- training(cat_split)
cat_test <- testing(cat_split)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
An Example Model Fit
Letâ€™s fit another PH and add some nonlinear terms via splines:

# First add all of the predictors...
f <- event_time ~ . -
  # Then remove geocoded columns
  longitude - latitude +
  # Then add them back as spline terms
  ns(longitude, df = 5) + ns(latitude, df = 5)

cat_wflow <- workflow(f, proportional_hazards())

cph_spline_fit <- cat_wflow %>%
  fit(data = cat_train)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Predictions
For our demo data set of n = 50 cats, the largest event time was 329.
Weâ€™ll make predictions from 8 days to 320 days:

demo_cat_preds <- augment(cph_spline_fit, demo_cats, eval_time = 8:320)
demo_cat_preds %>% select(1:3)
#> # A tibble: 50 Ã— 3
#>    .pred              .pred_time event_time
#>    <list>                  <dbl>     <Surv>
#>  1 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       58.9        36 
#>  2 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>      181.         16+
#>  3 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>      106.         12+
#>  4 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       62.7        16 
#>  5 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       31.4        22 
#>  6 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       88.5        16 
#>  7 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       48.2       294 
#>  8 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>      109.         68+
#>  9 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>       60.9        31 
#> 10 <tibble [313 Ã— 5]>      104.         24+
#> # â„¹ 40 more rows

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Predicted Survival Probabilities

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Concordance
The concordance statistic (â€œc-indexâ€, Harrell et al (1996)) is a metric that quantifies that the rank order of the times is consistent with some model score (e.g., a survival probability).

It takes into account censoring and does not depend on a specific evaluation time. The range of values is \([-1, 1]\).

demo_cat_preds %>% 
  concordance_survival(event_time, estimate = .pred_time)
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 3
#>   .metric              .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>                <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 concordance_survival standard       0.668

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Time-dependent metrics
We pick specific time points to evaluate the model (depending on our problem) such as every 30 days:

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Classification(ish) Metrics
Most dynamic metrics convert the survival probabilities to events and non-events based on some probability threshold.
From there, we can apply existing classification metrics, such as

Brier Score (for calibration)
Area under the ROC curve (for separation)

Weâ€™ll talk about both of these.
There are more details on dynamics metrics at tidymodels.org.

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Using the Right Evaluation Strategy
There are a lot of papers with different methods of evaluating survival data with dynamic metrics. Almost all of these are created to help score/screen predictors.
The problem is that these metrics are not derived for estimated model probabilities. Statistically, this is a very different problem (and not applicable here).
Instead, tidymodels uses an approach similar to causal inference called inverse probability of censoring weights (IPCW). The main reference is Graf et al (1999).

title: 4 - Evaluating models
4 - Evaluating models
text: Converting to Events

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Class Probability Estimates
The predicted class probabilities are then:
\[
\begin{align}
Pr[y_{i\tau} = 1] &= 1- \hat{S}(\tau; \boldsymbol{x}_{i})\notag \\
Pr[y_{i\tau} = 0] &= \hat{S}(\tau; \boldsymbol{x}_{i}) \notag
\end{align}
\]

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Inverse Probability Weighting
Without censored data points, this conversion would yield appropriate performance estimates.

Otherwise, there is the potential for bias due to missingness.

One approach is to weight observations based on the likelihood that each sample is censored (regardless of their actual status).

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Probability of Censoring
\(\hat{C}(t^*;\boldsymbol{x}_{i})\) is the probability that sample \(i\) is censored at some time \(t^*\) where
\[
t^*=
\begin{cases}
t_i - \epsilon &  \text{if }t_i \le \tau \\ \notag
\tau           &  \text{if }t_i > \tau  \notag
\end{cases}
\] (default: \(\epsilon = 10^{-10}\))

Case weights \(w_i(\tau)\) are the inverse of these probabilities and \(W(\tau)\) is their sum.

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Probability of Censoring Model
We currently only estimate the probability of non-informative right censoring (i.e.Â the predictors \(x_i\) are ignored).

Our estimator \(\hat{C}(T;x_i)\) is the â€œreverse Kaplan-Meierâ€ (RKM, Korn (1986)) curve that inverts the event indicator.
This is the same for each sample at time \(\tau\).

(We may expand this API in the future)
The RKM curve is attached to the parsnip model object. For our data setâ€¦

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Reverse Kaplan-Meier Curve

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Inverse Weights

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Brier Score
The Brier score is a measure of calibration originally meant for classification models:
\[
Brier = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N\sum_{k=1}^C (y_{ik} - \hat{\pi}_{ik})^2
\]
For our application, we have two classes (event and non-event) and case weights
\[
Brier(\tau) = \frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^N \sum_{k=0}^1w_i(\tau)I(y_{i\tau} = k)(y_{i\tau} - \hat{\pi}_{i\tau})^2
\]

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Demonstration Cat Brier Scores

demo_brier <- brier_survival(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
demo_brier %>% slice(1:5)
#> # A tibble: 5 Ã— 4
#>   .metric        .estimator .eval_time .estimate
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1 brier_survival standard            8    0.0197
#> 2 brier_survival standard            9    0.0394
#> 3 brier_survival standard           10    0.0601
#> 4 brier_survival standard           11    0.0616
#> 5 brier_survival standard           12    0.0776

and also

brier_survival_integrated(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 3
#>   .metric                   .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>                     <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 brier_survival_integrated standard       0.152

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Brier Scores Over Time

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Area Under the ROC Curve
This is more straightforward.

We can use the standard ROC curve machinery once we have the indicators, probabilities, and censoring weights at time \(\tau\) (Hung and Chiang (2010)).

ROC curves measure the separation between events and non-events and are ignorant of how well-calibrated the probabilities are.

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Demonstration Cat ROC AUC

demo_row_auc <- roc_auc_survival(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
demo_row_auc
#> # A tibble: 313 Ã— 4
#>    .metric          .estimator .eval_time .estimate
#>    <chr>            <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1 roc_auc_survival standard            8     0.596
#>  2 roc_auc_survival standard            9     0.566
#>  3 roc_auc_survival standard           10     0.487
#>  4 roc_auc_survival standard           11     0.483
#>  5 roc_auc_survival standard           12     0.571
#>  6 roc_auc_survival standard           13     0.574
#>  7 roc_auc_survival standard           14     0.678
#>  8 roc_auc_survival standard           15     0.739
#>  9 roc_auc_survival standard           16     0.643
#> 10 roc_auc_survival standard           17     0.630
#> # â„¹ 303 more rows

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: ROC AUC Over Time

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Using Evaluation Times
When predicting, you can get predictions at any values of \(\tau\).

During model development, we suggest picking a more focused set of evaluation times (for computational time).

You should also pick a time to perform your optimizations/comparisons and list that value first in the vector. If 90 days was of interest, you might use

times <- c(90, 30, 60, 120)

  augment(cat_train, eval_time = 8:320) %>%
  brier_survival(truth = event_time, .pred)

mc_cv(cat_train, times = 10)

A validation set is just another type of resample

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Cross-validation 
Weâ€™ll use this setup:

set.seed(123)
cat_folds <- vfold_cv(cat_train, v = 10)
cat_folds

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

cat_res %>%
  collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 4 Ã— 7
#>   .metric        .estimator .eval_time  mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <dbl> <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 brier_survival standard           30 0.212    10 0.00487 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 brier_survival standard           60 0.245    10 0.00756 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 3 brier_survival standard           90 0.205    10 0.00990 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 4 brier_survival standard          120 0.158    10 0.0106  Preprocessor1_Model1


collect_metrics() is one of a suite of collect_*() functions that can be used to work with columns of tuning results. Most columns in a tuning result prefixed with . have a corresponding collect_*() function with options for common summaries.


We can reliably measure performance using only the training data ğŸ‰

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_spec <- rand_forest(trees = 1000) %>% 
  set_engine("aorsf") %>% 
  set_mode("censored regression")
rf_spec
#> Random Forest Model Specification (censored regression)
#> 
#> Main Arguments:
#>   trees = 1000
#> 
#> Computational engine: aorsf

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_wflow <- workflow(event_time ~ ., rf_spec)
rf_wflow
#> â•â• Workflow â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Your turn

Use fit_resamples() and rf_wflow to:

keep predictions
compute metrics




âˆ’+
08:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

ctrl_cat <- control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE)

# Random forest uses random numbers so set the seed first
set.seed(2)
rf_res <- fit_resamples(rf_wflow, cat_folds, eval_time = c(90, 30, 60, 120), control = ctrl_cat)

collect_metrics(rf_res)
#> # A tibble: 4 Ã— 7
#>   .metric        .estimator .eval_time  mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <dbl> <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 brier_survival standard           30 0.210    10 0.00455 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 brier_survival standard           60 0.241    10 0.00796 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 3 brier_survival standard           90 0.199    10 0.00960 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 4 brier_survival standard          120 0.151    10 0.00840 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: The whole game - status update

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
The final fit 
Suppose that we are happy with our random forest model.
Letâ€™s fit the model on the training set and verify our performance using the test set.

Weâ€™ve shown you fit() and predict() (+ augment()) but there is a shortcut:

# cat_split has train + test info
final_fit <- last_fit(rf_wflow, cat_split, eval_time = c(90, 30, 60, 120)) 

final_fit
#> # Resampling results
#> # Manual resampling 
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6
#>   splits             id               .metrics .notes   .predictions .workflow 
#>   <list>             <chr>            <list>   <list>   <list>       <list>    
#> 1 <split [1765/442]> train/test split <tibble> <tibble> <tibble>     <workflow>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
What is in final_fit? 

collect_metrics(final_fit)
#> # A tibble: 4 Ã— 5
#>   .metric        .estimator .eval_time .estimate .config             
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 brier_survival standard           30     0.217 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 brier_survival standard           60     0.225 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 3 brier_survival standard           90     0.160 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 4 brier_survival standard          120     0.108 Preprocessor1_Model1


These are metrics computed with the test set

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
What is in final_fit? 

extract_workflow(final_fit)
#> â•â• Workflow [trained] â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

How do you fit a linear model in R? 
How many different ways can you think of?



âˆ’+
03:00





lm for linear model
glm for generalized linear model (e.g.Â logistic regression)
glmnet for regularized regression
keras for regression using TensorFlow
stan for Bayesian regression
spark for large data sets

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Models weâ€™ll be using today

Proportional hazards (PH) model
Decision tree

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text: Proportional hazards model

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text: Proportional hazards model

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Proportional hazards model













Hazard modeled via a baseline hazard and a linear combination of predictors:

\(\lambda(t | x_i) = \lambda_0(t) \cdot \exp (x_i^T \beta)\)

The hazard is proportional over all time \(t\), and thus also the probability of survival is proportional.

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text: Decision tree

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Decision tree













Series of splits or if/then statements based on predictors
First the tree grows until some condition is met (maximum depth, no more data)
Then the tree is pruned to reduce its complexity

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text: Decision tree

title: 3 - What makes a model?
section: All models are wrong, but some are useful!
text:
All models are wrong, but some are useful!


PH model










Decision tree

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Workflows bind preprocessors and models


Explain that PCA that is a preprocessor / dimensionality reduction, used to decorrelate data

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text: What is wrong with this?

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Why a workflow()? 


Most importantly, a workflow captures the entire modeling process: fit() and predict() apply to the preprocessing steps in addition to the actual model fit




You can use other preprocessors besides formulas (more on feature engineering if time permits!)




They can help organize your work when working with multiple models




Workflows handle new data better than base R tools in terms of new factor levels


Two ways workflows handle levels better than base R:

Enforces that new levels are not allowed at prediction time (this is an optional check that can be turned off)
Restores missing levels that were present at fit time, but happen to be missing at prediction time (like, if your â€œnewâ€ data just doesnâ€™t have an instance of that level)

title: 3 - What makes a model?
3 - What makes a model?
text:
A model workflow   

tree_spec <-
  decision_tree() %>% 
  set_mode("censored regression")

workflow() %>%
  add_formula(event_time ~ .) %>%
  add_model(tree_spec) %>%
  fit(data = cat_train) 
#> â•â• Workflow [trained] â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
#> Preprocessor: Formula
#> Model: decision_tree()
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Preprocessor â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> event_time ~ .
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> $rpart
#> n= 1765 
#> 
#> node), split, n, deviance, yval
#>       * denotes terminal node
#> 
#> 1) root 1765 1981.0090 1.0000000  
#>   2) neutered=no,unknown 696  576.4117 0.5937228 *
#>   3) neutered=yes 1069 1318.2450 1.1714650  
#>     6) intake_condition=ill_mild,ill_moderatete,normal,under_age_or_weight,other 921 1063.5830 1.0808970 *
#>     7) intake_condition=feral,fractious 148  195.7649 2.3866130 *
#> 
#> $survfit
#> 
#> Call: prodlim::prodlim(formula = form, data = data)
#> 
#> 
#> 
#> Right-censored response of a survival model
#> 
#> No.Observations: 1765 
#> 
#> Pattern:
#>                 Freq
#>  event          1116
#>  right.censored 649 
#> 
#> $levels
#> [1] "0.593722848021763" "1.08089686322063"  "2.38661313111009" 
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "pecRpart"

title: 3 - What makes a model?
text:
Predict with your model   
How do you use your new tree_fit model?

tree_spec <-
  decision_tree() %>% 
  set_mode("censored regression")

tree_fit <-
  workflow(event_time ~ ., tree_spec) %>% 
  fit(data = cat_train)

The whole game - status update


Stress that fitting a model on the entire training set was only for illustrating how to fit a model




https://workshops.tidymodels.org

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on shelter cats



The city of Long Beach releases data on animals at the Long Beach Animal Shelter.
Our dataset is a sample of the cats entering and leaving the shelter.
Type ?cat_adoption or check the sources to learn more about this dataset, including references.






Credit: https://www.svgrepo.com/svg/194185/pet-house-kennel

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on shelter cats

N = 2257
A time-to-event outcome, consisting of the time spent at the shelter and the event status.
An event is a cat being homed by the Long Beach animal shelter.
If a cat is transfered to a different organization that works to home them, this is recorded as a non-event.
Several nominal variables like sex, intake type and condition, as well as fur color.
Two numeric variables for the location of the intake or capture, latitiude and logitude.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on shelter cats

library(tidymodels)
library(survival)
library(modeldata)

cat_adoption

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Make the outcome 

cat_adoption <- cat_adoption %>% 
  mutate(event_time = Surv(time, event), .keep = "unused", .before = everything())

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending
For machine learning, we typically split data into training and test sets:


The training set is used to estimate model parameters.
The test set is used to find an independent assessment of model performance.



Do not ğŸš« use the test set during training.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending

Spending too much data in training prevents us from computing a good assessment of predictive performance.



Spending too much data in testing prevents us from computing a good estimate of model parameters.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending 

set.seed(123)
cat_split <- initial_split(cat_adoption, prop = 0.8)
cat_train <- training(cat_split)
cat_test <- testing(cat_split)

nrow(cat_train)
#> [1] 1805
nrow(cat_test)
#> [1] 452

text:
Your turn

cat_split

How much data in training vs testing? This function uses a good default, but this depends on your specific goal/data We will talk about more powerful ways of splitting, like stratification, later

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Your turn

Split your data so 20% is held out for the test set.
Try out different values in set.seed() to see how the results change.

Extension/Challenge: This is a simple random split. Which other types of splits can you think of and does rsample offer corresponding functions?

05:00

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending 
Weâ€™ll use this setup:

set.seed(27)
in_demo <- sample.int(nrow(cat_adoption), 50)
demo_cats <- cat_adoption %>% slice(in_demo)

set.seed(123)
cat_split <- initial_split(cat_adoption %>% slice(-in_demo), prop = 0.8)
cat_train <- training(cat_split)
cat_test <- testing(cat_split)

title: 2 - Your data budget

set.seed(123)
cat_split <- initial_split(cat_adoption %>% slice(-in_demo), prop = 0.8)
cat_train <- training(cat_split)
cat_test <- testing(cat_split)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluation time
We pick specific time points to evaluate the model (depending on our problem) such as every 30 days:

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Brier Scores

demo_brier <- brier_survival(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
demo_brier %>% filter(.eval_time %in% seq(30, 300, by = 30))
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 4
#>    .metric        .estimator .eval_time .estimate
#>    <chr>          <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1 brier_survival standard           30     0.163
#>  2 brier_survival standard           60     0.170
#>  3 brier_survival standard           90     0.151
#>  4 brier_survival standard          120     0.174
#>  5 brier_survival standard          150     0.164
#>  6 brier_survival standard          180     0.188
#>  7 brier_survival standard          210     0.147
#>  8 brier_survival standard          240     0.156
#>  9 brier_survival standard          270     0.161
#> 10 brier_survival standard          300     0.125

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Brier Scores Over Evaluation Time

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Integrated Brier Score

brier_survival_integrated(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 3
#>   .metric                   .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>                     <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 brier_survival_integrated standard       0.152

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Area Under the ROC Curve

demo_row_auc <- roc_auc_survival(demo_cat_preds, truth = event_time, .pred)
demo_row_auc %>% filter(.eval_time %in% seq(30, 300, by = 30))
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 4
#>    .metric          .estimator .eval_time .estimate
#>    <chr>            <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1 roc_auc_survival standard           30     0.660
#>  2 roc_auc_survival standard           60     0.679
#>  3 roc_auc_survival standard           90     0.582
#>  4 roc_auc_survival standard          120     0.582
#>  5 roc_auc_survival standard          150     0.515
#>  6 roc_auc_survival standard          180     0.515
#>  7 roc_auc_survival standard          210     0.490
#>  8 roc_auc_survival standard          240     0.490
#>  9 roc_auc_survival standard          270     0.490
#> 10 roc_auc_survival standard          300     0.679

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: ROC AUC Over Evaluation Time

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Tuning parameters
Some model or preprocessing parameters cannot be estimated directly from the data.

Some examples:

Tree depth in decision trees
Number of neighbors in a K-nearest neighbor model

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Optimize tuning parameters

Try different values and measure their performance.



Find good values for these parameters.




Once the value(s) of the parameter(s) are determined, a model can be finalized by fitting the model to the entire training set.

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Optimize tuning parameters
The main two strategies for optimization are:


Grid search ğŸ’  which tests a pre-defined set of candidate values
Iterative search ğŸŒ€ which suggests/estimates new values of candidate parameters to evaluate

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Specifying tuning parameters
Letâ€™s take our previous random forest workflow and tag for tuning the minimum number of data points in each node:

rf_spec <- rand_forest(min_n = tune()) %>% 
  set_engine("aorsf") %>% 
  set_mode("censored regression")

rf_wflow <- workflow(event_time ~ ., rf_spec)
rf_wflow
#> â•â• Workflow â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
#> Preprocessor: Formula
#> Model: rand_forest()
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Preprocessor â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> event_time ~ .
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> Random Forest Model Specification (censored regression)
#> 
#> Main Arguments:
#>   min_n = tune()
#> 
#> Computational engine: aorsf

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Try out multiple values
tune_grid() works similar to fit_resamples() but covers multiple parameter values:

set.seed(22)
rf_res <- tune_grid(
  rf_wflow,
  cat_folds,
  eval_time = c(90, 30, 60, 120),
  grid = 5
)

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Compare results
Inspecting results and selecting the best-performing hyperparameter(s):

show_best(rf_res)
#> # A tibble: 5 Ã— 8
#>   min_n .metric        .estimator .eval_time  mean     n std_err .config        
#>   <int> <chr>          <chr>           <dbl> <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>          
#> 1    33 brier_survival standard           90 0.197    10 0.00937 Preprocessor1_â€¦
#> 2    31 brier_survival standard           90 0.198    10 0.00953 Preprocessor1_â€¦
#> 3    13 brier_survival standard           90 0.198    10 0.00956 Preprocessor1_â€¦
#> 4    21 brier_survival standard           90 0.199    10 0.00960 Preprocessor1_â€¦
#> 5     6 brier_survival standard           90 0.199    10 0.00977 Preprocessor1_â€¦

best_parameter <- select_best(rf_res)
best_parameter
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>   min_n .config             
#>   <int> <chr>               
#> 1    33 Preprocessor1_Model1

collect_metrics() and autoplot() are also available.

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
The final fit

rf_wflow <- finalize_workflow(rf_wflow, best_parameter)

final_fit <- last_fit(rf_wflow, cat_split, eval_time = c(90, 30, 60, 120)) 

collect_metrics(final_fit)
#> # A tibble: 4 Ã— 5
#>   .metric        .estimator .eval_time .estimate .config             
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 brier_survival standard           30     0.221 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 brier_survival standard           60     0.225 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 3 brier_survival standard           90     0.160 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 4 brier_survival standard          120     0.107 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: 5 - Tuning models
text:
Your turn

Modify your model workflow to tune one or more parameters.
Use grid search to find the best parameter(s).
